Heading:
Post-Pulwama impact? Pakistan removes ISI chief, gets a new hardlinerLt Gen Asim Munir, believed to have approved Pulwama terror attack, has been
replaced as ISI chief with Lt Gen Faiz Hameed, who was once accused of
stealing 2018 national election for Imran Khan's party, PTI.

Boeing says it made mistake in 737 MAX plane after crashesChairman and Chief Executive Dennis Muilenburg acknowledged the company made
a mistake in failing to disclose a defective cockpit warning light on its 737
MAX to regulators and customers, and said that failure has been part of
reviews by global regulators.

00:44Indian family found dead in their residence in USFour Indian nationals have been found dead in their residence in America's
Iowa. The Telugu-speaking couple and their two children have allegedly died
of bullet injuries. More details are awaited.

Power mostly restored after massive blackout in Argentina, but questions remainEntire Argentina was out of power after the country's grid collapsed at 7 am
on Sunday.

US: Four of Indian family shot dead in Iowa houseFour Indians, including two boys, have been gunned down at their home in Des
Moines, the capital city of Iowa in the United States.

Sudan's Bashir charged with corruption, in first appearance since AprilBashir was charged last month with incitement and involvement in the killing
of protesters, and prosecutors also want him questioned over suspected money
laundering and terrorism financing.

Hong Kong leader says sorry as protesters insist she quitsHong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam on Sunday apologised for the way the
government had handled the extradition draft law, which had been scheduled
for debate last Wednesday, but gave no further insight into its fate.

Pakistan removes ISI spy agency head after eight months, appoints hardlinerLieutenant General Faiz Hameed, a former senior ISI figure, was appointed
director general of the agency, according to a statement by the military's
press wing, which did not explain the re-shuffle.

Massive blackout leaves millions without power in Argentina and UruguayArgentina and Uruguay were scrambling to restore power to millions of people
after a massive power failure hit the Argentine grid early on Sunday,
Argentina’s Energy Secretariat said.

Hong Kong becomes sea of black as thousands protest extradition billSunday’s march looked likely to match in scale one a week earlier that
brought as many as 1 million people out to express their concern over the
former British colony’s relations with mainland China.

Man smashes oxygen mask, damages cabin window of Turkish Airlines plane minutes after takeoff from IstanbulA man, travelling in a Turkish Airlines plane, started screaming a few
minutes after takeoff from Istanbul and began smashing an oxygen mask box and
then a cabin window before pushing flight attendants aside and rushing toward
the cockpit. Flight attendants said the man was complaining about not being
able to breathe.

Passengers subdue screaming man on board Turkish Airlines jetFlight attendants calmed the man down after about 15 minutes and he was taken
back to a seat as the plane continued toward Khartoum. Flight attendants said
the man was complaining about not being able to breathe.

Sudan crisis: How protest over bread prices led to more than 100 dead, bodies floating in NileIn December, protests broke out in Sudan after an economic crisis emptied
bank machines and forced the government to triple the price of bread. What
started as a fight for bread prices soon morphed into a nationwide movement,
resulting in President Omar al-Bashir being ousted. On June 3, the military
council in Sudan tried to disperse the pro-democracy protesters in Khartoum
by opening fire on the crowds and killing over 100 people, according to local
doctors.

Gulf of Oman tanker attack: One oil tanker anchored off UAE coast, US accuses Iran of blastsThursday's attacks, which also hit Norwegian tanker Front Altair, have
heightened tensions between Iran and the United States and its Gulf allies
after similar blasts in May struck four ships, including two Saudi oil
tankers, off the UAE.

Israel PM Benjamin Netanyahu's wife Sara admits criminal wrongdoing in meals catering caseSara Netanyahu, along with a government employee, fraudulently obtained from
the state more than $100,000 for hundreds of meals supplied by restaurants.

Pak fails to fulfil 25 of 27 FATF points, downgrading by IMF, World Bank to continueWith this, multilateral lenders like the IMF, the World Bank and the EU may
continue downgrading Pakistan, making its financial situation more
precarious.

How India evacuated nearly 2,300 citizens during Israel-Lebanon war 2006The evacuation was done via neighbouring Syria. The families travelled by
road to Syria and then from its capital, Damascus, undertook an onward
journey to India.

Dubai: 6-year-old Indian boy dies after being left in bus for hoursMohamed Farhan Faisal from Kerala was a student of Islamic Centre in Al Quoz
and had dozed off after boarding the bus. He was left behind after all other
students disembarked outside the centre at 8 am, the Khaleej Times reported.

French billionaires who promised millions to help rebuild Notre Dame, fail to donate a single pennyAlmost $1 billion was promised by some of France's richest and most powerful
families and companies, some of whom sought to outbid each other, in the
hours and days after the inferno.

Magnitude 7.4 earthquake hits island chain off New Zealand, no tsunami threatThe area the quake struck is called the Kermadec Islands, about 800
kilometers (497 miles) northeast of New Zealand's North Island.

Will shoot in your face: US cops harass family after minor takes doll from storeA police officer followed them, approached their vehicle with his gun drawn
and started threatening them. "I am going to shoot you in your face," the
officer said. According to the reports, the threat was made in front of the
couple's children who were in the rear of the car.

Terrorism 'gravest threat' people face in Asia: EAM Jaishankar at CICA SummitJaishankar said India supports a peace and reconciliation process in
Afghanistan that is Afghan-led and Afghan-owned.

Indian-origin woman asleep at wheel jailed for killing another driver in UKAnusha Ranganathan was sentenced to two-and-a-half years in prison at Oxford
Crown Court on Friday after pleading guilty to causing the death of
70-year-old Patricia Robinson.

Hong Kong suspends controversial extradition bill after massive protestsAfter widespread anger, Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam on Saturday delayed
indefinitely a proposed law that would allow extraditions to mainland China.
